data.text: @alpix17 @EricPhDing Yes. Everything is down to testing, the sample used (this one is small), what's defined as a "covid toe", individual immune response, timing of testing etc.
@elisaperego78 @EricPhDing This is some possible explanations they offer. https://t.co/KZTr5PE9W6

@EricPhDing Of course as a reasonable person I have to acknowledge that I can't prove it was covid, it is possible it is something else. But what? It isn't chilblains, it persists in warm weather and is chronic, though worsened by cold. If I hear any better explanations I will be open.

@EricPhDing This study shows exactly my case. Can't prove it was covid, but it is likely it was. The authors don't state it is impossible covid caused it, just cite the lack of evidence. They blamed lockdown but lockdown over and the issue persists. At times hard to walk.

@EricPhDing I have covid toes, since I had a cold in January 2021 during extreme lockdown. Never had this before. I also didn't get Omicron despite two household contacts and no booster. I am sure it was covid, but can't prove it.

@EricPhDing They most likely are. The testing employed by the authors in a small sample of 23 could not prove the tests in question can detect prior CoV-2 infection. Quite a few of the children involved in the study had household contacts with covid or had acute covid symptoms themselves
@EricPhDing A lot of the photos in comments look like people who are wearing ill-fitted shoes.
@EricPhDing Doesn't say that. Read the paper properly before tweeting about it.
